Graphical abstract Highlights ► Kinetic study with an industrial Pd-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst for selective acetylene hydrogenation. ► Integral fixed bed reactor at different process conditions. ► Successful application of modeling results to the industrial reactor. The selective hydrogenation of ethyne is one process to remove traces of ethyne from steam cracker cuts during the production of ethene. Even though Pd-Ag/Al2O3 catalysts are predominantly used in industrial C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation reactors, a detailed kinetic study with this catalyst type has not yet been published in the open literature. For this reason, kinetic measurements were carried out on a Pd-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst in an integral fixed bed reactor at different process conditions for the selective hydrogenation of ethyne. The results of these measurements were fitted on different kinetic models ranging from a classical Hougen–Watson, Langmuir–Hinshelwood and Rideal–Eley approach up to simple power law equations. The kinetic model with the best fit was found by statistical and thermodynamical evaluations of all models and their respective kinetic parameters. This model is based on a Langmuir–Hinshelwood reaction mechanism involving two different active sites for the hydrogenation of ethyne and ethene. The kinetic measurements were not dependent on mass and heat transfer as demonstrated by using the criteria from Mears and the Weisz–Prater as well as for the Damkoehler numbers in 3rd and 4th order. Finally the performance of a bypass reactor, running in parallel to an industrial C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation reactor, was successfully calculated with a reactor model. Keywords Ethyne hydrogenation Ethene Ethane Palladium Silver Alumina Kinetic Mass and heat transfer Thermodynamic consistency 1 Introduction Ethene is mainly produced by steam cracking of naphtha [1]. This cracking process produces also impurities e.g. ethyne that causes an irreversible damage of the catalysts used in downstream processes of the steam cracker (for example Ziegler–Natta catalysts in the polymerization of ethene). The ethyne content has to be reduced to concentrations lower than 1ppmv to avoid this damage [2]. The removal of ethyne is carried out by selective hydrogenation to ethene. Thereby an ethene gain of the steam cracker is achievable which has got additional economic value [3]. The amount of this ethene gain is linked with the selectivity of the ethyne hydrogenation catalyst. Originally nickel, iron and cobalt containing catalysts were used in the selective hydrogenation of ethyne but sulfur compounds had to be added to minimize ethene losses. Furthermore an undesired polymerization of ethyne is taking place resulting in an agglomeration of the catalyst and thus regenerations have to be performed regularly [4]. In the 1950s Bond et al. proved palladium to be the most active and selective metal in the hydrogenation of ethyne [5]. About 20 years later a new catalyst type was commercially used containing 0.04wt.% palladium impregnated on Al2O3 pellets [4]. Another ten years later bimetallic catalyst systems and especially Pd-Ag/Al2O3 catalysts were established in the industry and are still used by today [6,7]. These catalysts are characterized by an egg shell distribution of palladium and silver over the catalyst pellet to reduce the influence of mass transfer resistance on the reactions [8]. The type of catalyst, investigated in this article, is used in a process called C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation. A requirement of this process is the separation of the C2-hydrocarbons ethyne, ethene and ethane from the cracked gas of the steam cracker. As described by Borodzinski and Bond [9], the necessary hydrogen for the removal of ethyne is added into the reactor where the following three reactions are taking place: (1) C2H2 +H2 →C2H4 Δ R H 1 =−176kJ/mol (2) C2H4 +H2 →C2H6 Δ R H 2 =−138kJ/mol (3) 2C2H2 +2H2 →C4H8 Δ R H 3 =−109kJ/mol The selective hydrogenation of ethyne to ethene in Eq. (1) is the desired reaction. Simultaneously ethene is hydrogenated to ethane according to Eq. (2). Furthermore ethyne is, as shown in Eq. (3), hydrooligomerized to butenes (1-butene, cis-2-butene and trans-2-butene). The kinetics of the selective hydrogenation of ethyne have already been very often a subject of research [10–23]. Based on the postulated reaction mechanisms different kinetic models were fitted on the measured kinetic data. An overview about the reported models is given by Borodzinski and Bond [24]. A similarity of all investigations was the rate-determining step of the reactions that turned out to be the surface reactions, or in other words the hydrogen addition to the hydrocarbons. For this reason only Langmuir–Hinshelwood, Rideal–Eley and power law approaches were reported. Gva and Kho [12], Men'shchikov et al. [15], Schbib et al. [16] as well as Godinez et al. [22] published kinetic models which are applicable for a fitting on measured kinetic data and shown in Figs. 1–4 . The remaining models from the literature were not applied for a fitting on measured kinetic data because of the following reasons: • The kinetic approaches, reported by Bos [10], Borodzinski and Cybulski [13], Moustofi et al. [17], Turek [18] as well as Zhvanetskii and Berenblyum [19], are based on model combinations taken from other kinetic studies in the literature. • Aduriz [11], Moses [14] and Duisenbanev [20] did not present kinetic parameters. • The temperature range, applied during the investigations of Vincent and Gonzales [23], was quite different from the common process conditions of selective hydrogenation of ethyne. • Huang et al. [21] only modeled the kinetics of the ethyne hydrogenation but not the kinetics of the formation of ethane or of the butenes. Kinetic models and their parameters were often not evaluated statistically and much less thermodynamically as usually necessary for a final evaluation of the model quality. This is also the case for the selective hydrogenation of ethyne. Standard deviations of the kinetic parameters were only presented by Borodzinski and Cybulski [13], Turek [18] and Huang et al. [21]. Thermodynamical evaluations of the kinetic parameters have never been carried out so far. Even though Pd-Ag/Al2O3 catalysts are predominantly used in industrial C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation reactors, a kinetic study on this catalyst type was only carried out by Huang et al. [21] up to now. These authors investigated a catalyst containing 1.36wt.% of palladium. This palladium content is much higher compared to commercial C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation catalysts which have palladium contents in the range of 0.035wt.%. Therefore the objective of this article is to show the results of a kinetic study on a Pd-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst with about 0.035wt.% of palladium. The kinetic model mirroring the kinetic data most exactly will be found by statistical and thermodynamical evaluations of all kinetic models and their respective parameters. With the help of this model, conclusions can be drawn for the reaction mechanisms. Thereby also mass and heat transfers will be investigated with respect to their influences on the kinetics. Moreover the kinetic model will be used to calculate an industrial bypass reactor for the C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation filled with the catalyst applied during the kinetic measurements in this work. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst The catalyst used in this kinetic work contains 0.035wt.% Pd and 0.017wt.% Ag (crystallite size=6nm) on an Al2O3 carrier (BET surface area=12.2m2/g, pore volume=0.45cm3/g). Furthermore this catalyst showed the best performance in a stability study which was published in another article [25]. In this study the performance of several catalyst samples was investigated and the reasons for the best performance were described. 2.2 Kinetic measurements Three different test gases delivered from Linde AG were used during the kinetic experiments. The composition of these test gases is given in Table 1 . The catalytic measurements were performed in a test rig and in an integral reactor that are shown in Figs. 5 and 6 . The gas is flowing downwards the reactor through the catalyst bed. After leaving the reactor the gaseous product is depressurized and analyzed with a GC-FID. The test conditions, adjusted during the kinetic measurements, were determined by using Design of Experiments (DOE). First the influencing factors had to be chosen. In case of the C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation, these influencing factors were the gas flow V ˙ g , the reactor pressure P and the hydrogen/ethyne-mole ratio MR. Next the number of steps of these influencing factors, the objective variables and the test plan had to be defined. In this case three steps of the influencing factors were decided which were derived from typical process conditions of a C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation reactor as given in Table 2 . The steps of the influencing factors are summarized in Table 3 . The concentrations of the five components ethyne, ethene, ethane, hydrogen and butenes, as well as the temperatures within the test reactor were nominated as objective variables. The test plan was chosen by comparison of three designs of experiments generated with the software “STATISTICA” [26]. It concerned a full factorial design containing 27 test conditions, a central composite design containing 18 test conditions and, as shown in Table 4 , a fractional factorial design containing 9 test conditions. The fractional factorial design was chosen as the test plan for the kinetic measurements because of the lowest number of test conditions and the wide distribution of the test parameters over the parameter field (see Fig. 7 ). The specific description of the test plan is 33-1. The basis of this term represents the three steps of every influencing factor. The exponent of the term 33-1 stands for the three influencing factors and one influencing factor is mixed with all possible combinations of the other factors. Each of the 9 test conditions was adjusted by using five different catalyst volumes (3, 6, 9, 12 and 15ml). This resulted in 45 test series whereby concentration and temperature profiles across the reactor axis were obtained. The inlet temperature of the experimental reactor was varied between 20 and 95°C in steps of 5°C. Thus 720 measuring points were generated. 2.3 Kinetic modeling The mole balances n ˙ i of the five components are shown in Fig. 8 where r j is the rate of reaction j, R i is the component i related rate of change and m cat is the catalyst mass. The component i related rate of change is defined as the sum of the reaction rates the component i was converted with (ν =−1) or was formed with (ν =1): (4) R i = ∑ i = 1 N ′ v i , j ⋅ r j If ethyne (A), ethane (Ea) and butenes (B) were chosen as key components, then the concentrations of the non key components ethene (Ey) and hydrogen (H2) will be calculated from the concentrations of the key components according to Eqs. (5) and (6), respectively. (5) x Ey = x Ey 0 + x A 0 − x A − x Ea + x Ea 0 − 2 ⋅ x B + 2 ⋅ x B 0 (6) x H 2 = x H 2 0 − x A 0 + x A + x Ea 0 − x Ea The modeling of kinetics is always connected with heat and mass balances. Time-independent balances could be used because stationary test conditions were applied. The impulse balance was negligible due to constant reactor pressures. The heat balance was not considered because the temperature profile within the reactor could be measured. For these reasons, the kinetics of the process were modeled by solving the mass balances of the catalytic integral reactor in Eq. (7) only. During the kinetic modeling the mass balance R i in Eq. (7) is equaled with the component i related rate of change in Eq. (4). Furthermore the rates of reaction r j in Eq. (4) were substituted by the kinetic approaches. The common kinetic approach, shown in Eq. (8), can be transferred in every Langmuir–Hinshelwood-, Rideal–Eley- or Power law kinetic model. Next to the partial pressure p i Eq. (8) contains also the reaction orders n i,i as well as the number of active sites γ participated in the reaction j. The kinetic measurements were not performed isothermally. Therefore the temperature dependence of the rate constants k j and the adsorption constants K i,j was considered by the Arrhenius relation in Eq. (9) and by the relation of van’t Hoff in Eq. (10), respectively. (7) R i = n ˙ i ⋅ d X i d m cat (8) r j = k j ⋅ ∏ i = 1 N ′ p i n i , j ∏ i = 1 N ′ ( 1 + ∑ i = 1 N ′ K i , j ⋅ p i ) γ (9) k j = k j ∞ ⋅ exp − E j R ⋅ T (10) K i , j = K i , j ∞ ⋅ exp − Δ ads H i , j R ⋅ T The mass balance had to be developed for each of the three key components (ethyne, ethane and butenes) which led to a set of three ordinary nonlinear differential equations. The kinetic parameters were determined by solving this set of equations which had to be carried out numerically and simultaneously. Furthermore the statistic software “SAS” (Statistical Analyses System) was used [27]. This software includes the procedure “NLIN” providing different algorithms for nonlinear regression. The algorithm “DUD” was applied performing the secant method [28]. The kinetic parameters were varied by the algorithm until the stop criterion was reached. According to Eq. (11) the stop criterion is achieved as the residual sum of squares RSS reached a minimum. The kinetic parameters, estimated by reaching the minimized residual sum of squares RSS min, enabled the best fit on the measured kinetic data. The RSS was only calculated with the concentrations of the key components because the mass balances were exclusively solved for these. Hence the mole ratios of the key components were calculated x i cal and compared with the measured mole ratios x i meas . The mole ratios of the key components should have the same weight and therefore a weighing factor of Z =1/3 was introduced. Further details about the kinetic modeling are given in [29]. (11) R S S = ∑ Z ⋅ x A meas − x A cal x A meas 2 + Z ⋅ x Ea meas − x Ea cal x Ea meas 2 + Z ⋅ x B meas − x B cal x B meas 2 → minimum ! The measured kinetic data were fitted on 77 kinetic models. Thereby four of these models were taken from the literature and have been introduced in chapter 1 (see Figs. 1–4). All models were based on the following assumptions to be comparable: • The total hydrogenation of ethyne to ethane was negligible. • The formation of butenes was the only reaction considered in terms of creating heavy hydrocarbons because of the very low concentrations of 1,3-butadiene (up to 50ppmv) and n-butane (up to 14ppmv). • Ethene and butenes were formed on the same active sites. The 77 kinetic models included the following cases: • The rate-determining step could be adsorption or desorption of the components but also the surface reaction of the components. For this reason all kinetic models based on Hougen–Watson-, Langmuir–Hinshelwood- or Rideal–Eley-reaction mechanisms, but also power law equations were fitted on the results of the kinetic measurements. • The components were adsorbed on the same or on different active sites. 2.4 Evaluation of kinetic models and parameters 2.4.1 Statistical evaluation The statistical evaluation of the kinetic models was carried out by comparison of the minimized residual sum of squares RSS min and the standard deviations σ as well as the correlation matrix of the kinetic parameters. Moreover residual analyses and parity plots were drawn. Residual analyses were carried out by plotting the deviation between measured and calculated concentrations in dependence on the measured concentration. In case of parity plots, the measured and the calculated concentrations were drawn against each other. The standard deviation was calculated with Eq. (12). Therein h q represents every value that a kinetic parameter reached during the parameter estimation while h ¯ is the kinetic parameter estimated at the RSS min. Q is the number of calculation steps necessary for reaching the RSS min. The correlation matrix contains the binary correlation coefficients r hl calculated with Eq. (13). The binary correlation coefficient is representing the strength of the linear relationship between the two kinetic parameters h and l during the computer aided parameter estimation. The particular kinetic parameters h and l were placed at the top of each row and at the beginning of each line of the correlations matrix. The calculation of the correlation coefficient was also including the starting values of the parameter estimation and the kinetic parameters h ¯ and l ¯ . The latter were determined at the RSS min. If the correlation coefficient becomes r h l ≈ 1 , then a strong correlation will exist between the kinetic parameters h and l. In case of r hl =0 the two parameters are not correlating with each other. This particular catalyst was also used during the kinetic measurements. The bypass reactor was characterized as an adiabatic fixed bed reactor due to an insulation of the reactor walls and hence negligible heat losses. A representative process condition was calculated which is shown in Table 5 and measured at steady state. It was concluded that mass and heat balances had to be considered while the impulse balance could be neglected because of a pressure drop in the range of <0.1bar. The radial diffusion and radial thermal conduction were not considered because these effects were also negligible in axial direction [38]. This was proven by the criteria of the Bodenstein number Bo in Eq. (31). The Peclet number in axial direction Pe ax was calculated with Eq. (32) because a turbulent gas flow existed [38]. The turbulence of the gas flow was proven by the criteria for the Reynolds number of the gas flow Re in Eq. (33). Moreover plug flow conditions and a homogeneous distribution of the gas residence time were validated because the criterion in Eq. (34) was met [38]. Accordingly the gas and the catalyst can be treated as a pseudo-homogenous phase and the state variables were only depending on the axial position within the test reactor. Thus the bypass reactor can be calculated with a pseudo-homogenous, one-dimensional and adiabatic reactor model at steady state. This reactor model was coupled with the kinetics derived in the laboratory showing the best fit in the measured kinetic data. The mass and heat balances of such a reactor model including their initial conditions were shown in Eqs. (35) and (36). The average heat capacity c ¯ p and the average molecular weight M ¯ of the gas were determined as illustrated in [33]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Kinetic and evaluation of the models The results of the kinetic measurements are published in [29]. After the 77 kinetic models were fitted on the measured data, the minimized residual sum of squares RSS min was compared. This comparison is shown in Fig. 10 . Thus 45 models were not able to describe the kinetics of the C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation sufficiently because of high RSS min. In this respect, the exclusion criterion was set to RSS min >60 that was the case for the kinetic models 1–16, 19, 20, 22, 23, 26–29, 31, 33, 35 and 37–54. The RSS min and the significance of the kinetic parameters of the models with RSS min <60 are illustrated in Fig. 11 . Kinetic models with not significant or negative significant parameters were also neglected. Thus only the models 32, 34 and 55 were remaining. The kinetic equations of these models are shown in Fig. 12 . The RSS min and the kinetic parameters including their standard deviations of the three models are given in Table 6 . The models 3, 7, 16 and 32 are corresponding with the kinetic approaches reported by Gva and Kho [12], Men'shchikov et al. [15], Schbib et al. [16] as well as Godinez et al. [22]. The models 3, 7 and 16 are not able to describe the kinetics adequately. Model 32 is equivalent to the power law approach of Godinez et al. [22]. Model 34 is retained after neglecting the ethene partial pressure in model 32. According to the Bodenstein principle [38] this simplification is allowed because even at 100% hydrogen conversion, the change of the ethene concentration is at a maximum of ±1.3%. The lowest RSS min was determined with model 55 and therefore only this model was further treated. The reaction mechanism of model 55 is given in Fig. 13 and is based on a Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism with the following assumptions: • There are two different active sites (l1 and l2) which cannot be characterized more specifically. • Ethene is formed on site l1 by reaction of molecular adsorbed ethyne with two dissociatively adsorbed hydrogen atoms under participation of a surface bonded vinylidene species. Two vinyl intermediates and hydrogen are reacting to the butenes on the same active site. • Ethene is associatively adsorbed on site l2 and converted with dissociative adsorbed hydrogen atoms to ethane. Ethyne is also adsorbed on l2 but the conversion takes place predominantly on l1. • The rate-determining step of the formation of ethene and of the butenes is the addition of the first hydrogen atom (pretermed equilibrium) and the addition of the second hydrogen atom is rate determining during the hydrogenation of ethene. • Both active sites were not covered by further components because of the weak adsorption of hydrogen and ethene as well as the fast desorption of ethane and of the butenes. The different rate-determining steps in model 55 are understood as an indication for different hydrogen supply mechanisms. It is assumed the addition of dissociated hydrogen atoms on ethyne takes place on palladium while in accordance with Borodzsinski ethene is [9,13] hydrogenated via a hydrogen spillover effect. In case of the ethene hydrogenation, certain transfer resistances and distances have to be overcome. Finally the addition of the second hydrogen atom is rate determining. These assumption are also in agreement with the works of LeViness et al. [40], Sarkany et al. [41], Weiss et al. [42] as well as Al-Ammar and Webb [43–45]. Model 55 is the first kinetic approach for the selective hydrogenation of ethyne on a Pd-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst whereby kinetic parameters are presented and the formation of butenes is considered. Approximately 16% of the ethyne was reacting to the butenes which is in agreement with the results of Margitfalvi et al. [46]. The adsorption of the ethene was not considered in the adsorption term of model 55 because the adsorption constant of ethene was much smaller compared to the ethyne. This conclusion is confirmed by the results of Borodzinski and Cybulski [13] as well as of McGown [47]. These authors reported adsorption constants of ethene that were 2000 times smaller than the adsorption constants of ethyne. The residual analyses and the parity plots of the key components are shown in Figs. 14 and 15 . Hence all concentrations are mirrored sufficiently by model 55. However ethyne and ethane concentrations higher than 2000ppmv were reflected more accurately as lower concentrations. It is assumed a shift into another reaction mechanism is taking place at ethyne concentrations less than 2000ppmv. During this phase of reaction, ethane is not only formed on active site l2 but also on l1. The high deviations between the measured and calculated ethyne concentrations in case of low ethane levels are attributed to the hydrogenation of ethyne on both active sites (l1 and l2). The kinetic parameters have low standard deviations and low correlations in the ideal case [34]. Hence there are two disadvantages of model 55. The standard deviations of the kinetic parameters are high (±13 to ±59%) and there exists likewise strong correlations between the activation energies and the heat of adsorptions (see Fig. 16 ). High correlation coefficients were determined especially for E 1 and E 2, for E 1 and Δads H A,13, for E 3 and Δads H A,13 as well as for E 2 and Δads H A,2. These two disadvantages did not appear as the heats of adsorptions Δads H A,13 and Δads H A,2 were set to 0. This means the temperature dependence of the adsorption constants was neglected. This simplification is consistent with other workers whom determined very low heats of adsorption of ethyne on Pd/Al2O3 in the range between 0 and −14kJ/mol [10,15,17,18]. As the heats of adsorption in model 55 were set to 0 during the computer aided parameter estimation, the residual sum of squares RSS min in Table 7 was determined. This table also contains the determined kinetic parameters and their standard deviations. Especially the activation energies are higher than under consideration of the heats of adsorption (22–34kJ/mol vs. 11–16kJ/mol). The standard deviations of all kinetic parameters were much lower (±3 to ±21%) while the RSS min was only slightly increased from 18.7 up to 19.3. In addition the correlations between the kinetic parameters were also lower as shown by comparing Fig. 16 with Fig. 17 . The kinetic parameters of model 55 in Table 6 were also evaluated with respect to their physical-chemical meaning. At first the activation energies and heats of adsorptions were validated with regard to the thermodynamic rule of signs in Eq. (14) and Eq. (15), respectively. All activation energies are positive while all heats of adsorptions have negative values. Hence both values have a physical-chemical meaning. Secondly the criteria of Boudart [30] in Fig. 9 were adapted to the adsorption constants K A,13 and K A,2. This is illustrated in row 2 and 3 of Table 8 . The first as well as the second criteria are fulfilled in case of K A,13. The second criteria is met with K A,2 but the first is not. In this moment K A,2 is not immediately classified as a thermodynamic inconsistent parameter. In fact the estimate of K A,2 strongly depends on the estimate of Δads H A,2 caused by a reparameterization of the kinetic constants described in [29]. The reparameterization causes a high standard deviation of Δads H A,2 (−3 to −13kJ/mol) the adsorption constant K A,2∞ ranged between 0.25 and 8.23 1/bar. That means the change of the adsorption entropy Δ ads S A, 2 0 takes values between 15 and −11.5kJ/mol. In this way nearly the same numbers of positive as well as negative entropy differences Δ ads S A, 2 0 are determined. Accordingly, also the first criterion is met for K A,2. Boudart's criteria for K A,2∞ =0.251/bar as given in row 4 of Table 8. The third and fourth criteria are not met with both adsorption constants. Despite this fact, it is assumed, that both constants have a physical-chemical meaning. In this context, Boudart [30] reported the first and the second criteria have to be met for thermodynamical consistency. The third and fourth criteria are less rigid. These criteria only limit the range of values of the adsorption constants and are not valid for several examples. 3.2 Influence of mass and heat transfer on the kinetics The Mears criterion in Eq. (16) was deployed to validate the influence of film diffusion on the kinetics. Thereby the mass transfer coefficients β and the similarity numbers in Table 9 were used. These similarity numbers were calculated by means of the effective diffusion coefficient given in Table 10 . The reactions orders were taken from kinetic model 55 (n A,1 = n Ey,2 = n A,3 =1). Graphical presentations of the Mears criterion are given in Fig. 18 in dependence on the maximal and minimal mass transfer coefficient (β i max and β i min). The limitation of the kinetics by pore diffusion was evaluated by using the Weisz–Prater criterion in Eq. (21). The concentrations on the catalyst surface c s and in the bulk flow c were seen as equal. This was proven with Eq. (22) because the maximal difference of these concentrations was about 0.3%. The Weisz–Prater criterion is shown in Fig. 19 as a function of the maximal and minimal effective diffusion coefficient ( D i − m eff,max and D i − m eff,min ). The area between the two graphs contains each value the Mears criterion or the Weisz–Prater criterion reached during the kinetic measurements. Accordingly the kinetics were never influenced by film or pore diffusion because these criteria were always within the limits. The effective diffusion coefficient was predominantly determined by the coefficient for bulk diffusion because of big catalyst pore diameters and high reaction pressures. Furthermore the mass transfer rates were in average double compared to the reaction rates. For instance a mass transfer rate of 1.1×10−6 mol/s was present at a reaction rate of 1.96×10−6 mol/s. The influence of the heat transfer on the kinetics was reviewed with the Damkoehler number in 3rd and 4th order in Eq. (26) and (29), respectively. The heat transfer coefficient was determined by using similarity numbers and the thermal conductivity of the gas which are given in Table 11 . The thermal conductivity of the catalyst is also listed in this table. The temperatures of the gas flow T g and on the catalyst surface T s were considered to be equal due to a maximal difference of 0.1°C that was determined with Eq. (31). The graphs of the Damkoehler numbers are shown in Figs. 20 and 21 . These numbers are drawn in dependence on the maximal and the minimal heat transfer coefficient ( α g -cat max and α g -cat min ) or on the maximal and the minimal thermal conductivity of the catalyst ( λ cat max and λ cat min ). The limits of the Damkoehler numbers were not exceeded during the kinetic measurements. Therefore the kinetics are valid considering heat transfer. 3.3 Analysis of the bypass reactor The bypass reactor was calculated with the “MATLAB” program code given in [29]. Thereby the data of chemical media in Table 12 were used. The change of these data is low in dependence on the reactor conditions. Therefore the data of chemical media were calculated at an average reactor temperature of 50°C. The results of the reactor calculation were compared with the representative process condition of the bypass reactor in Table 2. The comparison of the measured and calculated process condition is illustrated in Fig. 22 . The measured temperatures T, conversion X i and yields Y i were calculated very exactly with the pseudo-homogeneous, one-dimensional and adiabatic reactor model. Insofar, this kind of reactor model is suitable for a calculation of C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation reactors which is in agreement with the results of other studies [34,48–50]. The yield of the butenes Y B was only calculated because the formation of butenes was not measured in the bypass reactor. 4 Conclusion Kinetic measurements were carried out by using the catalyst which showed the highest long-term stability in a laboratory reactor. The concept of Design of Experiment (DOE) was used to balance the number of experiments with the information content. For the experimental design, the software “STATISTICA” was used. The parameter ranges were chosen to mirror typical industrial conditions of a C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation reactor. A set of 77 different kinetic equations were used to model the experimental data and hence to determine all respective kinetic parameters. For the computer-aided parameter estimation, the software “SAS” was used. The kinetic model with the best fit was found by a statistical evaluation of all models and their respective kinetic parameters (residual sum of squares, parity plot and residual analysis as well as standard deviations of the kinetic parameter). Furthermore a thermodynamical evaluation was carried out with the model showing the best fit on the experimental data. This model was based on a Langmuir–Hinshelwood reaction mechanism involving two different active sites for the hydrogenation of ethyne and ethene. The kinetic measurements were not influenced by mass and heat transfer. This was validated by using the criteria from Mears and Weisz–Prater and the criteria for the Damkoehler numbers in 3rd and 4th order, respectively. In a final step, a bypass-reactor running in parallel to an industrial C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation reactor was filled with the catalyst that was used during the kinetic measurements. This bypass-reactor was described with a pseudo-homogenous, one-dimensional and adiabatic reactor model at steady state. Additionally the reactor model was coupled with the kinetic approach showing the best fit on the kinetic data. The corresponding set of differential equations was solved with the software “MATLAB” and a representative process condition of the bypass-reactor was recalculated. This process condition could be expressed very precisely by the reactor model. Acknowledgement The authors thank J. Kobe for the help with modeling in “SAS”. References [1] K. Weissermel H.-J. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydrogenation of ethyne is one process to remove traces of ethyne from steam cracker cuts during the production of ethene. Even though Pd-Ag/Al2O3 catalysts are predominantly used in industrial C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation reactors, a detailed kinetic study with this catalyst type has not yet been published in the open literature. For this reason, kinetic measurements were carried out on a Pd-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst in an integral fixed bed reactor at different process conditions for the selective hydrogenation of ethyne. The results of these measurements were fitted on different kinetic models ranging from a classical Hougen–Watson, Langmuir–Hinshelwood and Rideal–Eley approach up to simple power law equations. The kinetic model with the best fit was found by statistical and thermodynamical evaluations of all models and their respective kinetic parameters. This model is based on a Langmuir–Hinshelwood reaction mechanism involving two different active sites for the hydrogenation of ethyne and ethene. The kinetic measurements were not dependent on mass and heat transfer as demonstrated by using the criteria from Mears and the Weisz–Prater as well as for the Damkoehler numbers in 3rd and 4th order. Finally the performance of a bypass reactor, running in parallel to an industrial C2-tail end-selective hydrogenation reactor, was successfully calculated with a reactor model.
coredata.dc:title: Kinetics and reactor modeling of a Pd-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst during selective hydrogenation of ethyne
